Unit or Neutral Element

An element $e \in M$ is called a unit element or a neutral element with respect to the law of composition on $M$ if $ea = a = ae$ holds for all $a \in M$. Such a unit element $e$ is uniquely determined by its defining property; it is usually denoted as 1.
Cyclic group
A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.
Polynomial Ring

Given a commutative ring R, the polynomial ring R[X] is the set of all sequences (a_i) where a_i in R and a_i=0 for almost all i, equipped with addition and multiplication defined by (a_i)+(b_i)=(a_i+b_i) and (a_i) 
cdot (b_i)=(c_i) where c_i=
sum_{
u+
u=i} a_
u b_
u. Elements of R[X] can be written as 
sum_{i=0}^n a_i X^i where X is the sequence (0,1,0,0,...).
Trivial Ideals
In any ring $R$, the zero ideal $\{0\}$ and the unit ideal $R$ are called trivial ideals. These are the only ideals if $R$ is a field.
Factorial ring/unique factorization domain

An integral domain $R$ satisfying the conditions that every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ can be uniquely written, up to associatedness and order, as a product of irreducible elements, and every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ is a product of prime elements. An element of a unique factorization domain is irreducible if and only if it is prime.
Canonical Homomorphism
The canonical homomorphism $\\[Phi: R[X] \\longrightarrow R /(p)[X]\\]$ is a ring homomorphism that reduces the coefficients of a polynomial modulo a prime element $p$ in $R$.
Galois Group of a Polynomial Splitting Fields
The Galois group of a polynomial equation is the group of automorphisms of the splitting field of the polynomial that fix the base field. These automorphisms permute the roots of the polynomial.
Algebraic Element

Given a field extension $K \subset L$, an element $\alpha \in L$ is called algebraic over $K$ if it satisfies an algebraic equation over $K$, i.e., an equation $\alpha^{n}+c_{1} \alpha^{n-1}+\ldots+c_{n}=0$ with coefficients $c_{1}, \ldots, c_{n} \in K$.
Normal field extension

A normal field extension is an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. It is a prestage to Galois extensions. An algebraic field extension \\(K \subset L\\) is called normal if it satisfies the equivalent conditions of Theorem 4: (i) Every \\(K\\)-homomorphism \\(L \longrightarrow \bar{L}\\) into an algebraic closure \\(\bar{L}\\) of \\(L\\) restricts to an automorphism of \\(L\\). (ii) \\(L\\) is a splitting field of a family of polynomials in \\(K[X]\\). (iii) Every irreducible polynomial in \\(K[X]\\) that admits a zero in \\(L\\) decomposes over \\(L\\) completely into linear factors.
Center
The center of a group $G$ is defined as the centralizer of $G$, i.e., as $Z=Z_{G}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in G\} .$
Sign or Signature of a Permutation

The sign or signature of a permutation $\pi \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$, denoted as $\operatorname{sgn} \pi$, is defined by the product $\prod_{i<j} \frac{\pi(i)-\pi(j)}{i-j}$. The sign can only assume the values 1 and -1. If $\operatorname{sgn} \pi$ is positive, $\pi$ is called an even permutation, and an odd permutation otherwise.
Subset
A subset is a set where all of its elements are also contained within another set.
Inheritance_Analysis

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: The center of a group (ID: 9) is a concept that specifically applies to groups, including cyclic groups (ID: 1). Therefore, the concept of a cyclic group is a generalization of the concept of the center of a group, as the latter cannot exist without the former.
